facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1792 of 1970 was filed under section 116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1792 of 1970. Appeal under s. 116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated July 17, 1970 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Election Petition No. 1 of 1969.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated July 17, 1970 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Election Petition No. 1 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under s. 116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated July 17, 1970 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Election Petition No. 1 of 1969. K. Krishna Menon, D. P. Singh, Narayana Nettar and J. Francis, for the appellant.

facts.text: High Court of Assam and Nagaland dismissed the appellant's election petition on July 17, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ray, J.-This is an appeal from the judgment dated 17 July, 1970 of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland dismissing the appellants election petition.

facts.text: Election held in February 1969 for 37-Wokha Constituency to constitute new Legislative Assembly of Nagaland.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, respondent No. 11 Odyuo and respondents No. 2 and 3 were candidates at 37-Wokha Constituency at the election held in the month of February, 1969 for the purpose of constituting a new Legislative Assembly of the State of Nagaland.

facts.text: Respondent Odyuo was declared elected from 37-Wokha Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Odyuo was declared elected. Odyuo obtained 1517 votes and the appellant 1485 votes.

facts.text: Odyuo obtained 1517 votes and the appellant obtained 1485 votes in the election.

anchor.surface_text: Odyuo obtained 1517 votes and the appellant 1485 votes. Odyuo secured 32 votes more than the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant challenged the election of respondent Odyuo from 37-Wokha Constituency in Election Petition No. 1 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the election of the respondent Odyuo as a member from 37-Wokha Constituency in the Nagaland Constituent Assembly.

facts.text: Appellant alleged that result materially affected by improper reception of 348 votes cast for Odyuo by personnel of 12th Battalion Assam Rifles posted at Wokha and some wives, ineligible under section 20(3) of 1950 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds for impeaching the election were principally these. First, the result of the election in so far as it concerned the respondent Odyuo had been materially affected by the improper reception of 348 votes cast in his favour by the personnel of the 12th Battalion Assam Rifles then posted at Wokha and also by the wives of some of them who in view of section 20(3) of the Representation of the People Act, 1950 referred to for the sake of brevity as the 1950 Act were not eligible to be enrolled as voters in the electoral roll of the Wokha Constituency.

facts.text: Appellant alleged majority of 348 voters were not citizens of India, so their votes void.

anchor.surface_text: Second, the majority of those 348 voters were not citizens of India, and, therefore, the votes cast by them in favour of the respondent Odyuo were void.

facts.text: Appellant claimed that excluding 348 void votes or majority, appellant had majority of valid votes.

anchor.surface_text: Third, if the aforesaid 348 votes or the majority of them as void votes were left out of account, the appellant had secured a majority of valid votes.

facts.text: Personnel of 12th Battalion Assam Rifles had service qualification under 1950 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The personnel of the 12th Battalion Assam Rifles at Wokha had indisputably service qualification.

facts.text: Personnel of 12th Battalion resided at Wokha 10 years prior to preparation of electoral rolls and at time of preparation.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence that the personnel of the 12th Battalion had been residing at Wokha 10 years prior to the time of the preparation of the electoral rolls and at the time of preparation of the electoral rolls resided at Wokha.

facts.text: Service personnel made statements under section 20(5) that but for service qualification they would have been ordinarily resident at Wokha.

anchor.surface_text: The service personnel made statements under section 20(5) of the Act that but for their having the service qualification they would have been ordinarily residents at wokha.

facts.text: Service personnel stated their wives were residing with them and submitted prescribed forms to Registration Officer.

anchor.surface_text: They also made statements that their wives were residing with them. They submitted forms in the prescribed forms. These statements made under Rule 7 of the Registration of Electoral Rules, 1960 were submitted to the Registration Officer.

facts.text: Electoral Registration Officer accepted the statements as correct and registered the names of 12th Battalion personnel.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence is that the Electoral Registration Officer accepted the statements as correct and registered the names of the personnel of the 12th Battalion.

facts.text: No evidence to displace the statements of service personnel.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of section 20(5) of the 1950 Act is that statement of a member having service qualification is to be accepted as correct in the absence of evidence to the contrary. There was no evidence to displace the statements in the present case.

facts.text: Appellant alleged that of 348 service electors, 37 were not Indian citizens (35 Nepali, 2 Sikkimese), and rest except 69 not citizens.

anchor.surface_text: The contentions on behalf of the appellant were that of the 348 service electors 37 were not Indian citizens, 35 of them being Nepali and 2 Sikkimese and further that out of the remaining service electors excepting 69 the rest were not Indian citizens.

facts.text: Appellant's evidence on citizenship was hearsay and not corroborated.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the appellant is not substantive evidence, or any proof of the allegation. Part of it is hearsay and is not corroborated. The other part is not of evidentiary value.

facts.text: Service personnel declared themselves Indian citizens in statements (Exhibit 6 series and A series), verified by Record Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court correctly found that in the statements furnished by the service personnel being Exhibit 6 series and Exhibit A series, they declared themselves to be citizens of India and the statements were verified by the Record Officer.

facts.text: No objection raised to service personnel's names on citizenship grounds, no notice or opportunity to be heard.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also correctly held that no objection was taken at any stage and no notice was given to any member of the service personnel that their names would be objected to on the ground that they were not Indian citizens and they have not been given any opportunity of being heard in respect of the allegation.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The contentions advanced on behalf of the appellant fail. The appeal is dismissed with costs.
Appeal under s. 116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated July 17, 1970 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court

anchor.surface_text: Second, whether any of the electors registered as service electors in the last part of the said Electoral Roll were number Indian citizens.

anchor.surface_text: The civil court therefore would have numberjurisdiction to adjudicate upon a question whether the personnel of the 12th Battalion Assam Rifles in the present case were validly registered as service electors.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds for impeaching the election were principally these. First, the result of the election in so far as it concerned the respondent Odyuo had been materially affected by the improper reception of 348 votes cast in his favour by the personnel of the 12th Battalion Assam Rifles then posted at Wokha and also by the wives of some of them who in view of section 20 3  of the Representation of the People Act, 1950 referred to for the sake of brevity as the 1950 Act were number eligible to be enrolled as voters in the electoral roll of the Wokha Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: Third, if the aforesaid 348 votes or the majority of them as void votes were left out of account, the appellant had secured a majority of valid votes.

arguments.claim: Electoral Registration Officer had no jurisdiction to register the personnel of the 12th Battalion Assam Rifles as voters in Wokha Constituency because under section 20(3) they would be deemed ordinarily resident where but for service qualification they would have been ordinarily resident, not where posted.

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant in the present case was that the Electoral Registration Officer had numberjurisdiction to register the personnel of the 12th Battalion Assam Rifles as voters in Wokha Constituency because the service personnel under section 20 3  of the 1950 Act would be deemed to be ordinarily residents on any date in the constituency in which, but for his having such service qualification, he would have been ordinarily resident on that date.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a 10 years prior to the time of the preparation of the electoral rolls and at the time of preparation of the electoral rolls resided at Wokha. The ser

arguments.court_reasoning: Misreading of s.20(3); statements under s.20(5) that they would have been resident at Wokha accepted; fiction doesn't prevent registration where actually residing.

arguments.claim: Members having service qualification cannot be registered as voters in the constituency in which they are posted or stationed in service.

anchor.surface_text: The gist of the appellants contention is that the members having service qualification cannot, be registered as voters in the constituency in which they are posted or stationed in service and the Electoral Registration Officer would have numberjurisdiction to register the persons having service qualification as voters in the constituency in which they are stationed in service.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: be the place for ordinary residence and his home town or village would be the only place where he would be ordinarily resident. Such a companystructi

arguments.court_reasoning: Statutory fiction confers right at home but doesn't take away right to register where ordinarily residing including place of service if stated.

arguments.claim: Service personnel were not Indian citizens (37 not, 35 Nepali 2 Sikkimese; rest except 69 not).

anchor.surface_text: The contentions on behalf of the appellant were that of the 348 service electors 37 were number Indian citizens, 35 of them being Nepali and 2 Sikkimese and further that out of the remaining service electors excepting 69 the rest were number Indian citizens.

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant's evidence hearsay, not corroborated; PW6 evidence unreliable; declarations in exhibits affirm citizenship; verified by Record Officer.

arguments.claim: In registering the service electors the Registration Officer did not exercise his discretion but merely carried out the orders and directions of the Chief Electoral Officer.

anchor.surface_text: A contention was advanced on behalf of the appellant that in registering the service electors the Registration Officer did number exercise his discretion but merely carried out the orders and directions of the Chief Electoral Officer.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: also his evidence that when he asked the Record Officer at Shillong he learnt that many of the service personnel were number Indian citizens. The evi

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court found statements checked, verified, sorted; decision of statutory authority beyond challenge on record.

arguments.claim: Finality of the electoral roll cannot be challenged in a proceeding impeaching the validity of the election.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in B. M. Ramaswamy v. B. M. Krishnamurthy Ors.  1  held that the finality of the electoral roll cannot be challenged in a proceeding impeaching the validity of the election.

arguments.claim: Sections 14 to 24 of the 1950 Act are a complete code; s.30 bars civil court jurisdiction to question electoral roll or ERO decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of section 30 of the 1950 Act was construed by this Court in the recent decision in Kabul Singh v. Kundan Singh Ors.  2  to be that sections 14 to 24 of the 1950 Act are a complete code in the matter of preparation and maintenance of electoral rolls and section 30 of the 1950 Act does number confer jurisdiction on a civil court...

arguments.claim: Civil court has no jurisdiction to adjudicate whether personnel were validly registered as service electors.

anchor.surface_text: The civil court therefore would have numberjurisdiction to adjudicate upon a question whether the personnel of the 12th Battalion Assam Rifles in the present case were validly registered as service electors.

arguments.claim: Lack of ERO power to register in violation of statutes leads to improper reception of void votes under s.100(1)(d)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Baidyanath Panjiar v. Sitaram Mahto Ors.  1  held that the lack of power of the Electoral Registration Officer to register voters in violation of the provisions of the relevant statutes would lead to the ground of improper reception...

arguments.claim: Statements under s.20(5) accepted as correct absent evidence to contrary; ERO accepted and registered.

anchor.surface_text: The service personnel made statements under section 20 5  of the Act that but for their having the service qualification they would have been ordinarily residents at wokha... The effect of section 20 5  of the 1950 Act is that statement... There was numberevidence to displace... The evidence is that the Electoral Registration Officer accepted...

arguments.claim: Such a construction [service personnel only at home town] would be misreading s.20(3); fiction doesn't prevent registration where ordinarily residing even if place of service.

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant was that a member having service qualification can only be ordinarily resident at the constituency in which but for his having service qualification he would have been ordinarily resident on that date... Such a construction would be misreading section 20 3  of the 1950 Act...

arguments.claim: Appellant's evidence on non-citizenship is not substantive, hearsay, uncorroborated, no evidentiary value.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the appellant is not substantive evidence, or any proof of the allegation. Part of it is hearsay and is number companyroborated. The other part is number of evidentiary value.

arguments.claim: Service personnel declared citizenship in statements (Ex 6 & A series), verified by Record Officer; no objection or notice given; no opportunity to be heard.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court correctly found that in the statements furnished by the service personnel being Exhibit 6 series and Exhibit A series, they declared themselves to be citizens of India and the statements were verified by the Record Officer. The High Court also correctly held that no objection was taken...

arguments.claim: Overwhelming unrebutted evidence that service personnel are Indian citizens.

anchor.surface_text: On the contrary, the evidence oral as well as documentary is overwhelming and unrebutted that each member of the service personnel made a statement declaring himself to be an Indian citizen.

holdings.text: The finality of the electoral roll cannot be challenged in a proceeding impeaching the validity of the election.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in B. M. Ramaswamy v. B. M. Krishnamurthy Ors.  1  held that the finality of the electoral roll cannot be challenged in a proceeding impeaching the validity of the election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from B. M. Ramaswamy v. B. M. Krishnamurthy followed directly.

holdings.text: Sections 14 to 24 of the 1950 Act are a complete code in the matter of preparation and maintenance of electoral rolls and section 30 bars civil court jurisdiction to question electoral roll or decisions of Electoral Registration Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of section 30 of the 1950 Act was construed by this Court in the recent decision in Kabul Singh v. Kundan Singh Ors.  2  to be that sections 14 to 24 of the 1950 Act are a complete code in the matter of preparation and maintenance of electoral rolls and section 30 of the 1950 Act does not confer jurisdiction on a civil court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from Kabul Singh applied; ss.14-24 complete code, s.30 ousts civil jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Civil court has no jurisdiction to adjudicate whether the personnel of the 12th Battalion Assam Rifles were validly registered as service electors.

anchor.surface_text: The civil court therefore would have no jurisdiction to adjudicate upon a question whether the personnel of the 12th Battalion Assam Rifles in the present case were validly registered as service electors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from complete code in ss.14-24 and s.30 bar on jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Statement under section 20(5) of member having service qualification is accepted as correct absent evidence to the contrary; here no such evidence, so Electoral Registration Officer correctly registered them.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of section 20(5) of the 1950 Act is that statement of a member having service qualification is to be accepted as correct in the absence of evidence to the contrary. There was no evidence to displace the statements in the present case. The evidence is that the Electoral Registration Officer accepted the statements as correct and registered the names of the personnel of the 12th Battalion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.20(5); factual finding of no contrary evidence and ERO acceptance.

holdings.text: Statutory fiction in s.20(3) deems service personnel ordinarily resident at home constituency but does not prevent registration where they are actually ordinarily residing, including place of service, based on their statements.

anchor.surface_text: Such a construction would be misreading section 20(3) of the 1950 Act... The statutory fiction is intended to confer the right to be registered as electors at their home town or village but the fiction cannot take away the right of persons possessing service qualification to get themselves registered at a constituency in which they are ordinarily residing though such place happens to be their place of service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of s.20(3) fiction; does not oust actual residence claim under statements.

holdings.text: Electoral Registration Officer exercised discretion properly in registering service electors based on verified statements, not merely following orders.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the reasons and conclusion of the High Court that the decision of the statutory authority which acted on the declarations submitted by the service personnel verified and found to be correct was beyond any challenge on the materials on record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court findings affirmed; verification process described.

holdings.text: No evidence that service electors were not Indian citizens; appellant's evidence hearsay and uncorroborated; declarations of citizenship verified and accepted.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence to substantiate the allegation which was made that members of the service personnel were not Indian citizens. On the contrary, the evidence oral as well as documentary is overwhelming and unrebutted that each member of the service personnel made a statement declaring himself to be an Indian citizen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's proof rejected as hearsay; positive evidence of declarations and no prior objection.

holdings.text: Result of election not materially affected by improper reception or void votes under s.100(1)(d)(iii) as voters validly registered and citizens.

anchor.surface_text: The contentions advanced on behalf of the appellant fail. The appeal is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative from prior holdings on validity and citizenship; no basis for s.100 ground.

precedents.cited_proposition: lack of power of the Electoral Registration Officer to register voters in violation of the provisions of the relevant statutes would lead to the ground of improper reception, refusal or rejection of any vote or reception of any vote which is void and would be a ground for avoiding the election under section 100(1)(d)(iii) of the 1951 Act

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; all contentions of the appellant rejected; election of respondent Odyuo upheld.
